item.title: No Bosses - What It’s Like Working at a DAO
item.description: To start from the top, dOrg has no general management positions (CEO, CFO, etc). … Instead, roles are fluid, with people sliding into different roles depending on each project. Everyone who officially works at the company is a legal owner of its Vermont LLC, with each owner owning one share. Company decisions are voted on using tokens, which accrue as you complete projects for the company. … The company isn’t completely non-hierarchical, however.

item.title: Two Years Later, Where Is Occupy's Internet?
item.description: Let’s talk about Occupy for a minute. How do you view the movement in hindsight? I said it from day one, and I will say it again: It was just a practice. We have a great deal of infrastructure to build before we can really start to talk about independence/autonomy/liberty/justice. How might democratized tools and technologies play into popular unrest in the future? We will not rely upon tools that are designed to sell us out at our moment of greatest need.
